events.long_description:

Bring coins to buy heritage seeds and plants. Places for 25 adults. Children free.
A guided walk of history, heritage and plants in the historic Halfway House garden at Glenside, halfway along the original road between Wellington and Porirua.

events.id: Collection Store - Aratoi Back of House Tour-12 Bruce Street, Masterton-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Collection Store - Aratoi Back of House Tour
events.long_description:
Aratoi holds the only public collection of Art in the Wairarapa and we are opening up the doors for a very special weekend!

We care for nearly 3000 pieces of art, objects, taonga and natural history specimens held in our Collection Store. 

Take a tour behind the scenes with Sarah who will delight you with tales from the Collection plus explain how we care for our special objects and art.
A rare chance to go behind the scenes at Aratoi Wairarapa Museum of Art and History.
Head into the Collection Store with Director Sarah McClintock.

events.id: Bell Ringing Open Day - Wellington Cathedral of St Paul-Wellington Cathedral of St Paul, 2 Hill Street, Thorndon, Wellington-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Bell Ringing Open Day - Wellington Cathedral of St Paul
events.venue: Wellington Cathedral of St Paul, 2 Hill Street, Thorndon, Wellington
events.long_description:
Take a tour through our ringing chamber and belfry, and see our 140-year-old bells up close. You will have a chance to watch the ringers in action, and maybe even have a go at chiming our 1500kg tenor bell, the largest swinging bell in New Zealand! 

Discover the secret world of bells and bellringing, something the public doesn't normally get to see. You may have never known that people are pulling on the ropes to make the bells ring!

*One of the few towers in the world accessible by lift!

PLEASE NOTE:

*The 10:00 - 11:30 am session on 26/10 will take place at Old St Paul's, Mulgrave Street.
Join us for an open day in the bell tower of Wellington Cathedral of St Paul, where you can uncover its unique history and see the bellringers come out to play.

Discover the secret world of bells and bellringing, something the public doesn't normally get to see.

events.name: Kapiti Island Heritage Cruise
events.long_description:
T
his tour takes you "close up" to sites of real historical significance to our region and country. Experience a combination of on-board tour and on Island walking tour. The tour will highlight significant aspects of our natural and cultural heritage – including the conservation history associated with Kapiti Island- the role Kapiti Island played in the early settlement of the lower North Island and top of the South.
A Kapiti Island coastal tour with expert guided commentary takes you further and deeper into the exceptional nature and history of Kapiti Island.

events.id: Heritage Thorndon-Old St Pauls, Mulgrave St, Thorndon, Wellington-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Heritage Thorndon
events.venue: Old St Pauls, Mulgrave St, Thorndon, Wellington
events.long_description:
Your journey with Walk Wellington commences at Old St Paul's (Murphy Street) and then takes us through the Parliament precinct to Hill Street, and into Tinakori Road. We then loop around Glenbervie Terrace to continue along Tinakori Road to Bowen Street and then back to follow Ascot and Sydney Street West. We finish at Kaiwakatere (the Navigator) behind Parliament and off Bowen Street.
Explore New Zealand oldest suburb on foot.

events.id: Wait, there’s a Medical School in Wellington?-University of Otago, Wellington Hospital, 23A Mein St, Newtown-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Wait, there’s a Medical School in Wellington?
events.venue: University of Otago, Wellington Hospital, 23A Mein St, Newtown
events.long_description:
This event is an opportunity to reflect on and celebrate 150 years of training doctors in Aotearoa, and almost 50 years of medical and health science education and world-class research at our Wellington Hospital campus in Newtown. Together we look forward to envisioning the next 150 years of health education and research in the capital city! 
Join staff & students at the University of Otago Wellington (previously the Wellington School of Medicine) to celebrate 150 yrs of training doctors in Aotearoa.

events.id: Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour-Wellington Prison (closed), 1 Main Road Maupuia-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford Historic Walking Tour
events.long_description:
First settled in the 1350s, Mātai Moana / Mount Crawford has a rich and layered history of Māori settlement and conflict, early agriculture, and farming, military fortifications, and changing prison populations. 

Today, it is a predator-free paradise for a thriving native wildlife population, occasional filming site, and much-loved recreation space for locals and visitors alike.

Join Kate Curtis, history educator and creator of the Mātai Moana historic trail map, on a guided walking tour full of stories of life up the hill. The tour will begin outside the now-closed Wellington Prison, and end with a cuppa in the historic Miramar Prison Garden.

Children and on-leash dogs are welcome.
Explore Māori settlements, one of New Zealand's oldest farms, military fortifications, and prison buildings, on a guided walking tour of Mātai Moana, Miramar.

events.id: Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever walk tour-St Peters Church, 211 Willis Street, Wellington-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Georgina Beyer – Diamonds are Forever walk tour
events.venue: St Peters Church, 211 Willis Street, Wellington
events.long_description:
In 2004, Georgina Beyer, the first openly transgender MP in the world, famously confronted members of Destiny Church during the Enough Is Enough rally declaring, “Your hatred is totally intolerable!” Never a bystander, Georgina made a significant impact locally, nationally and internationally. Join us on this special 90-minute walk tour visiting key central Wellington sites that shaped her life and legacy.
Celebrate Georgina Beyer’s trailblazing courage. Join us on a walking tour through Wellington to honour her impact – locally, nationally and globally.

events.id: Katherine Mansfield’s Thorndon – A Guided Walking Tour-25 Tinakori Road, Thorndon, Wellington-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Katherine Mansfield’s Thorndon – A Guided Walking Tour
events.long_description:
"How hard is it to escape from places. However carefully one goes they hold you – you leave little bits of yourself fluttering on the fences – like rags and shreds of your very life.”
 Katherine Mansfield in a letter to Ida Baker, 1922
Explore the Thorndon that internationally acclaimed writer Katherine Mansfield knew and the traces of her legacy that remain in the landscape today.

events.id: Old High Court Open Evening-46 Ballance Street, Wellington-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Old High Court Open Evening
events.long_description:
Opened in 1881, the Old High Court in Wellington was the scene of some of the most significant court cases in the country. The open evening will give visitors the opportunity to walk through this impressive building, guided by knowledgeable staff from the Office of the Chief Justice and the Supreme Court who will be on hand to talk about the building, the courts, and the judges who have presided here.
The open evening at the Wellington Old High Court provides a unique opportunity to walk through the meticulously restored Category 1 Heritage Building.

events.id: Visit ANZ Bank archives and museum-Level 1, 2a Green Street, Newtown, Wellington-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Visit ANZ Bank archives and museum
events.long_description:
Hear about the origins of the first bank in New Zealand, see some of its oldest records, displays of banking equipment, early television commercials from various banks, and stories from 185 years of banking in this country.  Learn about the rich research resources held by the Archives covering many important organisations (including the Union Bank, Bank of Australasia, National Bank, Countrywide).
Get a different angle on Wellington history, through items ranging from Wakefield cheques to comic commercials featuring Clive James.

events.id: An exhibition 'From Kāinga to Village, Part 1: 1843-1920-Ōtaki Museum, 49 Main Street, Ōtaki-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: An exhibition 'From Kāinga to Village, Part 1: 1843-1920
events.long_description:
In 1843 Ngāti Raukawa were living in pā and  kāinga on Ōtaki beach. Three years later they had moved a short distant inland to a site planned as on the lines of an English village. The journey to the Ōtaki of today had begun. This exhibition is about the first 84 years of that journey.
Stories from Ōtaki’s early history about the people, events and things that shaped Ōtaki as it changed from a village to a town.

In 1843 Ngāti Raukawa were living in pā and  kāinga on Ōtaki beach.

The journey to the Ōtaki of today had begun.
This exhibition is about the first 84 years of that journey.
Stories from Ōtaki’s early history about the people, events and things that shaped Ōtaki as it changed from a village to a town.

events.id: Exhibition: Further revelation: Frances Hodgkins and British Modernism-Toi MAHARA, 20 Mahara Place, Waikanae-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Exhibition: Further revelation: Frances Hodgkins and British Modernism
events.long_description:
During this decade Hodgkins’ work changed radically as she developed one of the most distinctive styles of British modernism. She joined the Seven & Five Society in 1929 which included like-minded artists with whom she felt an affinity. In this exhibition you can see Hodgkins’ work alongside that of Cedric Morris, Christopher Wood and Ivon Hitchens, among others.
Explore the work of expatriate artist Frances Hodgkins and her fellow British modernists of the 1920s and early 1930s.

events.long_description:
Walkers gather for morning tea at the historic Khandallah Automatic Telephone Exchange, home of the Onslow Historical Society then set off for an hour or so’s walk through historic Ngaio, past 19th century cottages, grand houses and sites of historic interest. The moderate walk will be on paved surfaces.
2025 is the centenary of the Ngaio Town Hall, and the walk will take in even older buildings and sites of interest nearby.

events.id: The Founding Families of St. Joseph's Pāuatahanui-85 Paremata Haywards Rd-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: The Founding Families of St. Joseph's Pāuatahanui
events.long_description:
Brian Murphy, a descendant of the Murphy family who built St. Joseph's church, will lead this talk.  A small community of closely-linked families, with many coming from Roscommon in Ireland, established farms at Pāuatahanui and donated funds to build this timber Victorian-Gothic church.  
Hear the stories, with accompanying photos and maps, which bring to life the families who founded this beautiful church 147 years ago.

events.long_description:

The Wellington Branch of the NZ Society of Genealogists hosts a demonstration of online tools that make searching for your New Zealand families easier.

events.id: Silverstream Hospital: an illustrated presentation and tour-3 Reynolds Bach Drive, Lower Hutt, 5018-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Silverstream Hospital: an illustrated presentation and tour
events.long_description:
An illustrated presentation about the history of Silverstream Hospital, followed by a tour of its former site (now Silverstream Retreat). Originally operated by the US Navy during WWII to care for US troops sick or injured while fighting in the Pacific, it subsequently provided long term hospital care for the Wellington District, before closing in 1989.
A rare opportunity to learn about and tour the former site of Silverstream Hospital, originally used for US troops during WWII.

events.id: Nancy Adams: a Wellington botanist and artist-Te Papa, 55 Cable Street, Wellington-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Nancy Adams: a Wellington botanist and artist
events.long_description:
Nancy Adams (1926-2007) was one of Aotearoa’s most notable botanists and a talented artist. As well as being a prolific botany collector, Adams drew and painted an incredible number of botanical illustrations, and wrote popular books on New Zealand seaweed, trees and flora. 
Join curators from Te Papa’s Botany and Art teams for a back-of-house tour of the archive of Nancy Adams.

events.venue: Te Papa Tory St facility, 169 Tory Street, Te Aro, Wellington 6011
events.long_description:
Join Te Papa’s insect and art curators for an inspiring journey through the life and legacy of one of Aotearoa’s most passionate naturalists. By day Hudson worked as a humble post office clerk, but in his spare time he was out in the wilds of Wellington, collecting, studying, and meticulously illustrating insects.
Step into the fascinating world of George Vernon Hudson - New Zealand’s pioneer naturalist and the father of daylight saving!

events.name: George Pain: Grocer, Gentleman, Generous Benefactor
events.long_description:
An animation of George Pain is the centrepiece of an exhibition recognising his significant contribution to the early growth of Martinborough. His name lives on in the Pain and Kershaw Supermarket but the man himself has become a footnote to history. This exhibition gives him the place he deserves in local history.
George Pain (1846-1937) merchant, farmer, business owner and philanthropist comes to life to tell us his story in his own words.

events.venue: Fell Locomotive Museum, corner of SH2 and Lyon Street, Featherston

There are toy trains for children, or they can make the Hero of the Hill itself move.
Meet the Hero of the Hill: H199, the worlds sole surviving Fell Locomotive.

events.id: Waifilmfest presents: Never Forgotten: The Marines of Masterton-30 Jellicoe St, Martinborough-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Waifilmfest presents: Never Forgotten: The Marines of Masterton
events.long_description:
🎬 Waifilmfest Presents:

Never Forgotten: The Marines of Masterton (2025)

A debut feature documentary by local historian and filmmaker Mark Pacey
📍 Circus Cinema, Restaurant & Bar, 30 Jellicoe Street, Martinborough
🗓️ Sunday 9 November 2025 · 🕒 3:15 PM
🎟️ 
Cinema Tickets: Adults: $18, Seniors/Students: $15, Children: $13 
 · Q&A with Mark Pacey to follow

Never Forgotten uncovers the moving, untold story of the U.S. Marines stationed in Masterton during World War II. Through interviews, personal stories, and rich archival material, local historian and filmmaker Mark Pacey brings to life a unique chapter in Wairarapa’s wartime history—and the deep bonds formed between the soldiers and the community.
Uncover a hidden chapter of Wairarapa’s wartime past in Never Forgotten, a powerful debut documentary revealing the story of the U.S. Marines in Masterton.

Through interviews, personal stories, and rich archival material, local historian and filmmaker Mark Pacey brings to life a unique chapter in Wairarapa’s wartime history—and the deep bonds formed between the soldiers and the community.

Freemasonry dates from the Middle Ages and stonemasons who built the cathedrals and castles of Europe. From the early 1700s, men who were not craftsmen were also accepted into membership. Freemasons have been in New Zealand since the early 1800s, and currently have 4700 members in 176 Lodges. Freemasons first met in Wellington in 1842 and have met at different places around the city since that time. There are presently only two active Lodge rooms in Wellington City including at the Wellesley.
Learn about the history of this boutique hotel, the story of Freemasons around the world, and how the two connect.

events.id: Wellington’s Roaring Twenties – Boom time for high rise construction-The Wellesley Hotel, 2-8 Maginnity St, Wellington 6011-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Wellington’s Roaring Twenties – Boom time for high rise construction
events.venue: The Wellesley Hotel, 2-8 Maginnity St, Wellington 6011
events.long_description:
During the 1920s, Wellington grew rapidly as a result of the new technologies of the motor car, electricity, films, broadcasting and aviation and services such as rail, insurance, finance, road construction and government support for farm exports and research.
Join Richard Norman as he helps you to look with new eyes at the city’s heritage from the 1920s.

events.id: Practices of Compassion-Pukeahu Education Centre, 191 Tory Street-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Practices of Compassion
events.long_description:
Learn about the historic crèche established by Meri Hōhepa Suzanne Aubert and the Daughters of Our Lady of Compassion, now known as the Pukeahu Education Centre. Hear the stories of the practices of compassion led by the Sisters in early 20th century Wellington. 

Then, walk over to the Compassion Soup Kitchen on Tory Street where the Sisters of Compassion and their co-workers are still supporting people with kai, aroha and much more. 

This programme offers a unique look at the past and present practices of compassion emanating from these two influential and historic Wellington sites. Please bring along a cash koha for the Compassion Soup Kitchen. 
Explore the practices of the Sisters of Compassion then and now, through the lens of the historic crèche and the ongoing mahi of the Compassion Soup Kitchen.

events.id: Paekākāriki Station Museum & Pride Weekend-20 Tilley Road, Paekākāriki-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Paekākāriki Station Museum & Pride Weekend
events.long_description:
At Labour Weekend, we have a feature on the rainbow history of Paekākāriki, coinciding with 
Paekākāriki Pride weekend
. Come to celebrate local history and the rainbow communities that have shaped the Paekākāriki of today.

The station was built in 1909, replacing the station built around 1886 for the Wellington and Manawatu Railway Company’s line between Wellington and Longburn. The plan for the building is based on a design of work of George Alexander Troup (1863-1941), chief architect of New Zealand Railways, and later Mayor of Wellington (1927-1931).

During WWII, fifteen thousand U.S. Marines disembarked at the station for camps situated at Whareroa Farm, Queen Elizabeth Park and north Paekākāriki.

This museum is also the starting point for the Paekākāriki History Walk, the Arts Walk, and the Escarpment Trail.
Paekākāriki Station Museum celebrates our local heritage, including railway history, Tangata Whenua, early settlers and US Marines stationed during World War Two.

events.name: Heritage Trees in the Wellington Botanic Garden
events.venue: The Founders' Entrance, 101 Glenmore Street, Kelburn, Wellington
events.long_description:
This easy one-hour walk will focus on many of the notable specimen trees planted since 1868. The majority of the trees around the duck pond and its surrounds were planted in 1871 and 1872. This is the heart of the Wellington Botanic Garden where all the early plantings were carried out by the first administration. 
Join us for an enlightening heritage walk through the historic Wellington Botanic Garden, sharing the stories of heritage trees.

events.venue: Near 26 Bolton Street, Museum entrance, Wellington
events.long_description:
Hear stories about the jailers, judges and policemen who were dealing with criminals, as well as some of the villains and murderers that shocked earlier generations in Wellington. Find out about the duelling pistol that was involved in the deaths of a lawyer and a magistrate; and about an unsolved murder on a quiet farm road. There’s even a criminal or two.
Extraordinary stories about people who broke the law, as well as lawyers, policemen, jailers and judges. There's even a murder or two!

events.name: Living Victorian Village experience
events.long_description:
Step into the world of the Victorians in a vibrant living village where history comes to life. Explore original heritage buildings and authentic artefacts in an immersive, hands-on experience of 19th-century New Zealand. Afterwards, relax with a picnic on the village green while the kids enjoy traditional games and outdoor fun.
Discover the courage, character and community that worked, lived and played together forging Wairarapa from the soil up in Victorian Aotearoa.

events.id: The Lives and Legacies of Japanese Prisoners at Featherston Military Camp-70-72 Fitzherbert Street, Featherston-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: The Lives and Legacies of Japanese Prisoners at Featherston Military Camp
events.long_description:
Featherston was home to almost 1,000 Japanese prisoners of war during World War 2. They were imprisoned at the old World War 1 training camp just outside the town. Discover their stories, their artworks, and the legacy of their presence here, including the infamous 1943 "Featherston incident".
Come and hear Wairarapa history expert, Neil Frances, explore the Japanese prisoner of war experience in Featherston in World War 2.

events.id: Soldier Stories Walk-63 Western Lake Road, Featherston-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Soldier Stories Walk
events.long_description:
The cemetery contains 182 Commonwealth war graves, the bulk of them of men who died in the Featherston Military Camp from 1916 to 1919, including many deaths from the November 1918 influenza epidemic. Each tour is limited to 30 visitors.
Join eminent historian Neil Frances for a not-to-be-missed walk exploring the history of the Featherston Cemetery and the men who lie at rest there.

events.name: Behind the Scenes: How We Digitise Photos at the Wairarapa Archive
events.long_description:
Join us for a guided look at how we digitise our photo collections—from choosing what to preserve, to the tools and techniques we use. See how we protect the past while making it accessible for whānau, researchers, and the whole community.
Ever wondered how historic photos are preserved for future generations? Step behind the scenes at the Wairarapa Archive and find out!

events.id: Caring for your collections at home-3 Albert Street, Masterton-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Caring for your collections at home
events.long_description:
Join us for a hands-on session at the Wairarapa Archive and learn easy ways to protect your photographs, letters, and other family treasures. Our conservator will share expert tips to help your memories last a lifetime.
Turn your family treasures into taonga for the future with expert advice from a conservator.

events.id: Chinese Footprints: A Walking Tour of Chinese Wellington History-Trades' Hall, Wellington-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Chinese Footprints: A Walking Tour of Chinese Wellington History
events.long_description:
Chinese Footprints, led by Lynette Shum (Oral History Advisor, Alexander Turnbull Library), will take attendees on a walking tour exploring the rich history of the Chinese in Wellington, much of which has been erased and is now largely invisible to passers-by.
Join Lynette Shum (Oral History Advisor, Alexander Turnbull Library) to discover the rich history of Pōneke's Chinese community.

events.id: Wellington Heritage Festival: Past, Present, and Future of the Parliamentary Precinct-New Zealand Parliament Buildings, Wellington-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Wellington Heritage Festival: Past, Present, and Future of the Parliamentary Precinct
events.long_description:
Hear from Dave Wills, Manager of Parliament's Buildings Project Management Office, about how he and his team are future-proofing the Parliamentary Precinct to ensure it is a resilient and sustainable home for the seat of our democracy now and into the future. Learn about how we ensure heritage buildings evolve to meet modern parliamentary needs, the plans for the future of the Parliamentary Precinct, and how previous earthquake strengthening and resilience projects are holding up over time.
Join us for a behind the scenes look at what makes a parliamentary precinct work, and how it evolves over time to meet the changing needs of our democracy.

events.id: Matangireia - A Place for Māori at Parliament-New Zealand Parliament Buildings, Wellington-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Matangireia - A Place for Māori at Parliament
events.long_description:
Hear from Ellen Andersen, Director Kaiwhakahaere Tautiaki Taonga me Kaupapa Māori at Heritage New Zealand, about how Matangireia came about as a "place for Māori at Parliament" over a century ago, and how the stories and role of the room have evolved over time.
Join us to celebrate Wellington Heritage Festival with an insightful look at the history and stories of our historic Māori Affairs Committee Room, Matangireia.

events.id: Māoriland Film Festival presents: Special programme of films made in Ōtaki-68 Main Street, Ōtaki-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Māoriland Film Festival presents: Special programme of films made in Ōtaki
events.long_description:
The Wellington Heritage Festival proudly presents a special programme of films at the Māoriland Hub.

The films are:
- Te Hokinga Mai o Ngā Taonga Whitiāhua ki Raukawa
- The Lawnmower Men of Kapu
- The Gravedigger of Kapu
- Ruarangi
- Tuia Ngā Here
- Brolesque
The history of the celebrated Māoriland Film Festival (
maorilandfilm.co.nz
) has its origins in some of the earliest filmmaking in New Zealand. Come and watch the story of Māoriland, along with a special programme of films made in Ōtaki over the past 100 years.

events.id: Rototawai Historic Homestead: A must visit in South Wairarapa-808 Kahutara Rd, Wairarapa-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Rototawai Historic Homestead: A must visit in South Wairarapa
events.long_description:
Rototawai is a tranquil landscape and a restored historic homestead, located in a rural setting in South Wairarapa. A family property made available to the public to enjoy a private collection of art, a unique landscape and a historic home.
Come and explore this stunning historic homestead and art gallery, including beautiful gardens, heritage features, and breathtaking artworks.

events.id: Pumpkin Cottage Artists and Early Silverstream: a digital tour-Whirinaki Whare Taonga, 836 Fergusson Drive, Upper Hutt-Wellington Heritage Festival
events.name: Pumpkin Cottage Artists and Early Silverstream: a digital tour
events.venue: Whirinaki Whare Taonga, 836 Fergusson Drive, Upper Hutt
events.long_description:
The public launch of a new online resource linking paintings by artists associated with the Pumpkin Cottage school of en plein air impressionism with the Upper Hutt landscape they depicted in their paintings. As well as providing an introduction to this new resource, this event will include displays of some of the included works. Light refreshments will be served.
A launch event for a new online resource linking works by Pumpkin Cottage artists to the local Silverstream environment in which they were painted.
